part.title: Member Home: The User GUI Tool

sect1.title: Create new array study
sect1.para: Clicking on the create link, will take you to the page for editing studies, but the "Array Study Name" will be blank. Fill in the name for your study and then proceed with configuration as described in help for editing an existing array study. For an overview of the process of creating studies and orders, see Placing an Order with the Array Center.

sect1.title: Edit/Delete an existing array study
sect1.para: Use this link when you wish to edit or delete an array study. See Placing an Order with the Array Center for an overview of the process of defining studies and placing associated array orders.

To delete an array study, click on the "Delete Array Study" button associated with the study you wish to delete. Note that you will not be able to delete the study if it contains an experimental condition that is in use (has data loaded). If you are allowed to delete the study, you will be taken to a confirmation screen where you can verify that you wish to delete the study.

To edit the study, choose the "Edit Array Study" button associated with the study you wish to edit. From the resulting page, you access two configuration pages: the "Edit Array Study" page and the "Edit Study Components" page.

If you do not see the study you wish to edit as an available choice, it means that you are unable to write changes to the study. Most likely, you are not in a group that has write permissions for the study.
sect1.formalpara: Edit Array Study This page is divided into several sections. The "Edit Study Configuration" configuration allows configuration of information associated with the study. The "Edit Defaults for Conditions and Samples Associated with this Study" section allows users to set values that will be used repeatedly in editing study components. In the majority of cases, most values for experimental conditions and samples within a study are the same, so setting defaults will save users time in setting individual values. &mandatory; Finally, once you have added experimental conditions, there will be a table that shows the details for each experimental condition associated with the study. Note that once data is loaded, you will no longer be able to change fields associated with the loaded data.
sect1.para:
The following fields can be configured on the Edit Array Study page:
Study Name
This name identifies the array study. Currently, it must be unique across the system. Use the "Names In Use" link allows you to determine what study names are in use. Study names can be up to 128 characters in length, but longer names do not display well on all pages, so users are advised to select names around 30 characters in length. Once data is loaded for your study, you will no longer be able to change the name.
Study Owner/Group
The array study owner/group field identifies the PI/PI group who will own the study. Only users who are PIs are able to own studies. Once this field is set, the PI cannot be modified. The group can be modified by the PI if required via the Change permissions for array studies link. Most users have only one PI, so will have only one option here (unless their PI has several groups).
Start Date
This is the date that study was started. It will default to the current date if no date is specified.
Classification
Studies should be classified if possible--classification is used to search and sort studies. You cannot add new classifications, but can email GEOSS administrators to suggest new classifications.
Comments
These comments are sometimes displayed near the study names to help distiguish studies. Filling out this field is particularly useful to array center staff, as they look at many studies.
Chip Type
This is the default chip type for the study. Most studies only use one chip type, so setting this default saves specifying it repeatedly on the "Edit Study Components" page.
Species
This field specifies the default species associated with each experimental condition.
Number of samples per condition (biological replicates)
This field specifies the default number of samples per experimental conditions. Essentially, it indicates the number of biological replicates for each condition.
Number of chips per sample (chip replicates)
This field specifies the default number of chips per sample. This is the number of chip replicates, or technical replicates, associated with the sample.
Lab Notebook ID
This field specifies the default lab notebook ID associated with samples.
Lab Notebook Owner
This field specifies the default lab notebook owner associated with samples.
Sample type for microarray analysis
This field specifies the default sample type associated with the experimental condition.
Sample Origin
This field specifies the default sample origin associated with samples. Sample origin is used to make data more meaningful and is used later to supply MIAME information if you choose to publish your study in GEOSS.
Sample Manipulation
This field specifies the default sample manipulation associated with samples. Sample manipulation is used to make data more meaningful and is used later to supply MIAME information if you choose to publish your study in &product;.
Experimental Condition Name
This is your name for the experimental condition. It used to clarify the design of the study. Additionally, if you choose to publish your data through &product;, your experimental conditions will be identified using the name you specify here.
Short name
The array center requires a short name for each experimental condition. This name is used to label samples when they are brought to the lab for processing. It is also used in the filename of data files created by the array center staff user and is included in the &product; hybridization naming convention.
Species
This is the species associated with the experimental condition. If the appropriate species is not listed, please contact &product; Developers.
Sample Type for Microarray Analysis
This field describes the sample type associated with the experimental condition.
Notes
This is a descriptive field. It is used only if you choose to publish your study results in &product;. In that case, this information is used, along with the experimental condition names to populate the MIAME experimental factors field. You will still have an opportunity to modify the description of the experimental factors when you publish your data.
Description
This description can be used to specify additional information about an experimental condition. It is used only for display purposes.
Sample Name
This is a descriptive field used by the user to uniquely identify their sample. This name can be linked to the hybridization name so that result files associated with the biological replicates correspond to the sample name.
Chip Type
This is the chip type associated with the sample.
# of Chips (replicates)
This is the number of chips associated with this sample. It determines the number of chip replicates.
Lab Book ID
This field identifies the lab book ID associated with the sample.
Lab Book Owner
This field identifies the lab book owner associated with the lab book.
Sample Origin
This field specifies the sample origin associated with samples. Sample origin is used to make data more meaningful and is used later to supply MIAME information if you choose to publish your study in GEOSS.
Sample Manipulation
This field specifies the sample manipulation associated with samples. Sample manipulation is used to make data more meaningful and is used later to supply MIAME information if you choose to publish your study in GEOSS.

To add experimental conditions, specify the number of conditions to add, and click "Add Experimental Conditions". To save changes, click "Save Study". When configuration of a study is complete, the status (top line) with change to "COMPLETE". Once the study status is complete, you can "Order Chips from Array Center" if the installation supports an array center.

Clicking on the order button, takes you to the "Order Chips" page. This page displays a summary of chips associated with the study and what their order status is. If they have not yet been ordered, you can order chips by specifying associated information (PI/PI group, Special Center Affiliation, Billing code) and clicking the "Submit Order" button. This informs the array center that you would like them to order chips and ready to bring in samples for processing.

sect1.title: View All Array Studies
sect1.para: This link can be used to view a summary of all array studies that you have permission to view. The summary displays information on the study name, the organism being studied, the chip(s) used in the study, and the disease(s) being studied.
Note that you can sort summary information by any column by clicking on the button in the column header. To reverse sort, click on the button a second time.

You may also search through the studies and display a subset based on the search results. To search on a particular column, click on the checkbox associated with that column. Then specify the criteria you wish to search for in the input areas in the same cell as the checkbox.

You can access additional information by clicking on the "Source" or "Edit" links if they exist. Alternatively, if the study name is a link, you can follow it to view full details on the array study configuration.

sect1.title: View Array Study
sect1.para: This link can be used to view details of an array study that you have permission to view. The page displays information on the study name, the organism being studied, the conditions of the study, the chip(s) used in the study, and the disease(s) being studied. Additionally, the page provides a link to analysis result files, if there is an analysis associated with the study. There is also a button that provides a quick link to creating a custom data set using the study data to facilitate customized analysis of the data.

sect1.title: Change permissions for array studies
sect1.para: This link can be used to set permissions for array studies. Note that only PIs can change group ownership and read/write permissions for their studies. If you are not a PI, then you will have no studies listed under this link.

The following items can be configured:
Group
This can be used to change the group that the study is associated with. The permissions on the array study apply to this group only. Anyone who is not a member of the group will not have permissions to see the study. Anyone who is a member will have the permissions set here applied to them.
Group Read
This will allow users who are part of the group associated with the array study to read details pertaining to this study. This means that they will be able to see the chip data files associated with the study, but they cannot modify the study.
Group Write
This will allow users who are part of the group associated with the array study to write details pertaining to this study. This will allow them to modify the array study definition. They could, for example, add an experimental condition.

sect1.title: Load a study
sect1.para: This link can be used to load an array study. Note that this link is only available if your installation allows users to load data. To load a study, the study data file must first be uploaded via the Upload a file page. Data file format should be a single data file containing signal values for all hybridizations in the study. Once a file is uploaded, it will be available in the list of files to load from. You must also select the name of the array study that you are loading. Only studies that have a "COMPLETE" status can be loaded.
Once you have selected the study and data file, select "Load Data". You will receive an email when the data load is complete. The loaded data can then be used for analysis and publishing.

sect1.title: Create publishing information
sect1.para: This link can be used to initiation publication of array study data. For an overview of the publication process, see the Publishing your Data link.
On this page, you must specify initial information on the data you wish to publish. &mandatory;

listitem.para: This is the name that your publishing information is stored under. It should correspond to one experiment. It is used to identify this set of publishing information when you return to edit it using Edit/Delete/Submit publishing information.

Furthermore, this name will be used, in conjunction with the name of the owner of the data, as a header for published data. It also is a component of the url for the published data. If you wish to publish a direct url to your study, you may wish to use underscores instead of spaces in the name to make the url easier to remember (as spaces are converted to special characters within the url).

This description should summarize important information (like species and intent of experiment) about the array study you are publishing. The description will appear in a summary table of all published experiments and provided those who are browsing through the list with a brief description of your experiment.

If your study is tracked in the local &product; system, select it from the list. This allows the system to fill in some of the miame data for you from your existing study definition and will save you from having to type duplicate information. Additionally, it provides &product; information about the ownership information for the array study so that you do not need to specify it manually. If your study is not tracked by the system, then do not choose an associated study, but make sure to select a PI/PI group who owns the data.

You must select the PI/PI group that owns the information you intend to publish if you have not selected an associated study. The published information for the array study will be filed under the PI's name and the PI will be contacted to verify the desire to publish the information.

MIAME standards require that different information is stored depending on the type of experiment. Depending on the type of experiment specified here, you will be prompted to enter the appropriate types of MIAME information.

sect1.para: Once you have completed the necessary fields, click 'Next'. This will take you to the page that allows you to edit MIAME data for the array study.
You only need to go through this create process once. After you have created the MIAME record you can return to editing it via the Edit/Submit/Delete Publishing Information link.

sect1.title: Edit/Delete/Submit publishing information
sect1.para: This link allows you to edit, delete, and submit publishing information for an array study.
sect1.formalpara:
Editing and Submitting publishing information
To edit publishing information, click the "Edit" button for the appropriate study. The fields on the resulting page allow you to specify the appropriate MIAME information for the the kind of array study data that you are publishing. It is important to provide thorough information about your study so that the data is meaningful. If you associated the publishing information with and existing array study, many of the fields will have default values, taken from your array study configuration. You may modify these defaults. Help is available for each of the fields on the page itself, just click on the help link beside each question to see a description of what the question means. To remove the help popup, just click on the page outside of the popup.
sect1.para: If you are not yet ready to publish your data, but plan to continue editing at another time, select 'Save form'. If you have finished providing the MIAME information and are ready to publish the results, click 'Submit information'.

Once you submit the information, the public data administrator is emailed. Once they have verified the intent to publish data with the owner of the data, they will post the appropriate files on the public data part of the site. Data is now available for use by all.
If you wish to modify some of the descriptive information after the data has been published, you may do so. Simply return to the edit page, make the changes, and re-submit the information.
sect1.formalpara:
Deleting publishing information
If you have not previous submitted the publishing information, then you can delete it. To do this, simply click on the "Delete" button for the appropriate array study.
sect1.para: If you wish to delete a study that has already been published, you will need to contact the &product; administrator for assistance.

sect1.title: View all array orders
sect1.para: This page provides a brief view of all array orders that you have permission to see. Note that you will see information for all orders associated with groups that you are a member of that have the appropriate read permissions. Typically, you will not be able to edit orders. Occasionally, array center staff may unlock an order so that you can edit components of the order via the Edit/Delete an Existing Array Study interface.

sect1.title: Change permissions for array orders
sect1.para: This link can be used to set permissions for array orders. Note that only PIs can change group ownership and read/write permissions for their orders. If you are not a PI, then you will have no orders listed under this link.

The following items can be configured:
Group
This can be used to change the group that the order is associated with. The permissions on the array order apply to this group only. Anyone who is not a member of the group will not have permissions to see the order. Anyone who is a member will have the permissions set here applied to them.
Group Read
This will allow users who are part of the group associated with the array order to read details pertaining to this order. This means that they will be able to see the chip data files associated with the order, but they cannot modify the order.
Group Write
This will allow users who are part of the group associated with the array order to write details pertaining to this order. Typically array orders are locked, so users will be unable to write changes to orders even if they have write permission.

sect1.title: View my files
sect1.para: This link provides users with the ability to view their files. Users can have several types of files including chip data files, analysis files, and uploaded files. All files can be viewed and downloaded from this location.

Files can be viewed in one of two modes: directory tree mode or current directory only mode. Both views allow users to see all files and which mode to use is entirely a matter of personal preference. The directory tree mode shows the entire tree structure, which is more intuitive to many users. The current directory mode is slightly faster, however, which may be useful to users who must navigate a large number of files (array center staff). To switch between the two modes, click on the "View Current Directory Only" button or the "View Entire Directory Tree" button as appropriate.

The "View my files" page is divided into three distinct parts:
Directory Navigation
Regardless of the mode you use, you can navigate through the directory structure by clicking on the names of directories. Note that in the "Current Directory Only" view, ".." will take you up a directory and the "top" will take you to the top level directory for the current user. In "Directory Tree" view, the current directory is highlighted in yellow. Only the files in your current directory are displayed in the file viewer.
The directory structure format is fixed. The top level contains &product; login ids for every user who has files that you can see (i.e. you are in one of their groups). Under each user directory, you may see the following directories:
Data_Files
This directory contains subdirectories for each finished array order owned by the user. The subdirectories are named after the order number and contain the chip data files associated with that order.
Analysis_Files
This directory contains subdirectories for each analysis tree owned by the user. The subdirectories are named after the tree and contain the analysis files associated with that tree.
Upload
This directory contains uploaded files. Depending on what files the user has uploaded, there can be several subdirectories including: criteria, data, mas5, other, logo, and icon. Uploaded files are found in the appropriate subdirectory based on the type specified during the upload.
File Viewer
The file viewing component of the page displays all files in the current directory. You can view the file by clicking on the filename. If your browser understands how to display that file type, it will show it to you. Otherwise it will download it to your computer. Note that some downloads may be time consuming as some of chip data files are very large.
Some files may be deleted. Raw data files may not be deleted, but analysis files and uploaded files can be. To delete a file, click on the trash can icon on the far right that is associated with the file. Note that the quickest way to delete analysis files is to delete the entire analysis using Edit/Delete/Run an existing analysis tree.
The list of files displayed can be filtered using the "Filename Pattern" field. To use this field type in the pattern that the filename must contain and click "Select". This pattern will apply until you clear the "Filename Pattern" field and click "Select" again. For instance, if you only wish to see files of type "txt" in the "Filename Pattern" and click "Select". The view will be filtered accordingly.
Navigation Short Cuts
The short cuts are an alternative technique for navigating through directories and a provide quick ways to navigate to commonly viewed i areas. There are four short cuts:
View Files Owned By
If you are in several groups, it is often useful to look only at files owned by a specific user. This short cut is particularly useful to administrators and array center staff.
View Files Associated with Loaded Orders
This short cut allows users to go directly to the directory containing chip data files for a specific array order .
View Files Associated with Sample
This short cut allows users to look at all files associated with a specific sample. It allows users to select the sample based on the researcher's name for the sample. The short cut then navigates to the appropriate array order directory and uses the array center staff name for the sample in the "Filename Pattern" field. The result is a listing of all files associated with that sample. Note that you will need to manually clear the "Filename Pattern" field after using this short cut if you wish to view files not associated with the sample.
View Analysis Tree File Results
This short cut allows users to look at all files associated with a specific analysis tree.
To use a short cut, simple select the desired target and hit the associated "Go" button.

sect1.title: Change group ownership and read/write permissions for existing files
sect1.para: This link can be used to set permissions for user files. Note that for most data files, permissions will be set correctly given the permissions for the associated array order or array study. However, you may occasionally wish to change permissions on certain files so that other users in your groups can see them. Note that this page can get lengthy. Files are arranged alphabetically.

The following items can be configured:
Group
This can be used to change the group that the file is associated with. The permissions on the user file apply to this group only. Anyone who is not a member of the group will not have permissions to see the file. Anyone who is a member will have the permissions set here applied to them.
Group Read
This will allow users who are part of the group associated with the file to see and download the file.
Group Write
This allows users who are part of the group associated with the file to write to the file. In actuality, this provides very limited permissions. No users are allowed to overwrite or delete chip data files, so no permissions are granted for this type of file. Users can't overwrite other users' analysis files or uploaded files. This permission would allow users in your group to delete your analysis files and uploaded files though.

sect1.title: Upload a File
sect1.para:
This link allows users to upload files. Typically uploaded files are used to in association with data analysis. For an overview of this process, see Determining Tree Input. To upload a file, you must first specify the type of file you wish to upload. Several types have very specific formats that must be adhered to. Possible upload types include:
data
This filetype allows users to upload a file that contains all data for an array_study. Data should be in the single data file format. Uploading a file of this type makes it available for users to load a study. Note that users may not be able to load studies on all installations.
mas5
Users may upload mas5 data for individuals chips. This will result in the creation of a hybridization and the chip data will be loaded into the database. The data will then be available for use in analysis conditions. File format for this kind of upload is a Affymetrix mas5 txt fileAffymetrix mas5 txt file. The following fields must be specified when uploading mas5 data:
Hybridization Name
This field needs to be filled out if a mas5 file is being uploaded. The hybridization name, combined with the upload timestamp provides a unique identifier for the uploaded data. The name will be used when including uploaded hybridizations in analysis conditions.
Affymetrix Chip
This field needs to be filled out if a mas5 file is being uploaded. As a hybridization is being created, it is necessary to know the layout (chip type). If the correct chip type is not in the drop down box, contact the administrator for assistance.
analysis input
This filetype allows users to upload a file that is already appropriately formatted for use by analysis trees. This is useful if you wish to analyze results for currently unsupported data types, such as cDNA data. See Uploading external experiment data for a description of this format.
criteria
Criteria files can be used to facilitate creation of analysis conditions and analysis sets.
other
This file type can be used up upload any other type of file. Uploading files of this type will have no effect on GEOSS, except to store the file and make it available via the View My Files.
Regardless of which file type you choose, you will be asked to specify the following:
Filename
This field is optional. If you wish to give the file a different name than the name it has on the source system, you may specify that name in the filename field.
File to Upload
Specify the appropriate file to upload from your local machine.
Once all fields have been configured, click "Upload". Please note that loading a very large data file may take several minutes. If the file is too large, your browser may time out and return an error. This error reflects a timeout on the part of the browser, but does not necessarily mean that the file failed to load. Wait for a bit and then check whether the file has been loaded via the View My Files link. All uploaded files should be accessible from that interface.

sect1.title: View Quality Control records
sect1.para: To view the quality control information for a specific hybridization, select the hybridization from the drop down list and click "View QC". The quality control data is taken from the chip data files generated while running the array experiment. Note that not all hybridizations will have quality control data as the appropriate files may not have been present when the data was loaded.

sect1.title: Create a data file containing all data for one study
sect1.para: This link will create a data file that contains the signal values for all hybridizations is a specific study. This file is very similar in format to the files used as input to analysis trees.

Provide a filename and comments. Choose the array study you wish to obtain data from from the drop down box. Note that only studies that have all their associated data loaded are listed in the box as you clearly cannot get data for a study that has none loaded. Choose "Create Data File". The resulting data file will be loaded under your login id in the file viewer.

sect1.title: Create/Run a new Analysis Tree
sect1.para: This link allows users to create new analysis trees. For an overview of analysis trees, see Analyzing your data using analysis trees.

When you create a new tree, you must specify the name, the desired initial structure, and the source of input.
Analysis Tree Name
This name must be unique. Use the "Show list of used tree names" link to determine uniqueness. A combination of the analysis creation date and the input data name tends to be a useful naming convention.
Tree Structure
The "Initial node only" setting will result in your tree having only one node, "Quality Control", when it is created. For there you can go on to add additional nodes as necessary. The "Entire default tree" setting results in the tree's initial structure consisting of several nodes in an arrangement that is typically used by &product; analysis staff.
Analysis Input Data Source
To select a source, click on the radio button to the left of the desired source type, then click "Choose Source". All sources of the applicable type will be displayed in a table below the source radio buttons. Select the desired source for the tree. For an overview of the different source types (array study, analysis set, and public data), see Determining Tree Input.
Once you have set the appropriate values, click "Next" to create the tree and proceed to the Edit/Delete/Run an existing analysis tree page where you can refine the configuration of the new tree.

sect1.title: Edit/Delete/Run an existing Analysis Tree
sect1.para: This link allows users to edit, delete or run existing analysis trees. For an overview of analysis trees, see Analyzing your data using analysis trees.
sect1.formalpara:
Editing an existing analysis tree
The current node is the node that is highlighted in yellow. All configuration activities are performed on the current node. To change the current node, click on the pencil icon for node that you wish to make current. Configuring a tree involves several steps:
Adding Nodes
To add a new node to the tree, select the type of analysis from the "Choose" drop down list and click "Add Node". The new analysis node will use the output of the current node as input. Note that the list of possible analyses to add is restricted by the current node selection. The list only contains analyses that can use the output of the current node as input.
Only current versions of analyses are available in the "Choose" box (the version number is indicated by the number behind the analysis name).
Deleting Nodes
Nodes can be deleted by clicking on the trash can icon on the node. This will delete the node and all nodes below it in the tree structure. There is currently no confirmation, the nodes are just deleted.
Configuring Nodes
The configuration parameters for the current node are located on the right hand portion of the page. The parameters vary, based on the type of analysis. To obtain help on the parameters of each analysis, look at the help page for that analysis. It can be accessed by clicking on the name of the analysis inside the node.
The default tree should run successfully using the default values for each parameter.

Deleting an existing analysis tree
To delete an analysis tree, click on the "delete" button for the appropriate tree. Note that if the tree has been run, this will delete all associated input and output files (but not the actual chip data files used to generate the input file).

Running an existing analysis tree
Once the analysis tree has been configured, it can be run by clicking the "Run Analysis" button. This runs the tree, which typically takes a non-trivial amount of time. The actual amount of time depends largely on which nodes are included in the tree, the size of the input data set and the other load on the system while the analysis tree is being run. To provide a very general guideline, it takes about fifteen minutes to run the default tree on a data set that includes nine MG_U74Av2 chips. Large analyses can often take over a day to run.
sect1.para: Note that is some cases, after a new &product; release, the nodes in your tree may become obsolete. This relates to upgrading the node, the R version, or R libraries. If your tree contains obsolete nodes, the "Run Analysis" button will not be present, as you cannot run obsolete trees. However, the "Upgrade Tree" and "Copy Tree" buttons should appear. These buttons can be used to upgrade the tree, if possible. The "Upgrade Tree" button upgrades all obsolete nodes in the tree. If this action is successful, the "Run Analysis" button will reappear and you can run your tree again. Note that your result files from the older version of the tree will be overwritten. If you wish to preserve the results files from the older version, you can copy the tree instead of upgrading. This creates a copy of the old tree, then upgrades the versions on the copy. You then have two versions of the tree: an older one containing obsolete nodes and a new, upgraded one. When you run the new one, the old tree is unaffected, so you can still access the result files. All trees have an associated "versions.txt" file that shows the versions of softward that the tree results were generated with.

Due to the large amount of time involved in running trees, &product; will send you an email to notify you when the analysis is complete and the completion status. Analysis result files can be viewed via the View My Files. Note the navigational short cut at the bottom of the "View My Files" page that will take you directly to the results for a specific tree. If the tree did not complete successfully, see the Troubleshooting tree failures link for guidance.

sect1.title: Create new analysis condition
sect1.para: This link allows users to create new analysis conditions. For an overview of this process, see Determining tree input.

To create a new analysis condition, specify the condition name and description. As many analysis conditions can represent the same data (if many analyses are performed), it is helpful to provide a description even though it is not mandatory. Also choose the PI/PI group that will own the condition. This will allow others in the group to use the analysis condition. Click 'Next' to create the analysis condition. Then you will be ready to specify which hybridizations to include in the analysis condition.

sect1.title: Edit existing analysis conditions
sect1.para: This link allows users to edit existing analysis conditions. For an overview of this process, see Determining tree input.

This page allows users to modify hybridizations included in the analysis condition. To add hybridizations, choose the desired analysis condition and click "Add Hybridization". Click on the desired source, then click "Choose hybridization" source. The use of each source is as follows:
Analysis Conditions
An existing analysis condition can be used as the source for hybridizations. If this source is used, a list of analysis conditions you have permissions to read is displayed. You may select one or more analysis conditions by checking the checkbox beside the condition name. All hybridizations in all selected analysis conditions will be included in the current analysis condition once you click "Add hybrids to Condition".
Studies
An existing array study may be used as the source for hybridizations. If this source is used, a list of array studies you have permission to use is displayed. You may select one or more studies. All hybridizations in all selected studies will be included in the current analysis condition once you click "Add hybrids to Condition".
Experimental Conditions
An existing experimental condition may be used as the source for hybridizations. If this source is used, a list of experimental conditions that you have permission to use is displayed. You may select one or more experimental conditions. All hybridizations in all selected experimental conditions will be included in the current analysis condition once you click "Add hybrids to Condition".
Experimental conditions are easily confused with analysis conditions as analysis conditions are derived from experimental conditions. Remember that experimental conditions are defined as part of an array study and are used by array orders. They relate to a specific experimental intent and are unchanging. Analysis conditions often mimic experimental conditions (as we wish to analyze data based on the intent of the experiment). However analysis condition is entirely theoretical and is subject to change. Users can change the grouping of hybridizations in analysis conditions at any time.
Hybridizations
Existing hybridizations may also be used as the source for hybridizations. If this source is used, a list of hybridizations you can read is displayed. You may select one or more hybridizations. All hybridizations selected will be included in the current analysis condition once you click "Add hybrids to Condition".
This option provides direct access to hybridizations that have been created by uploading a mas5 data file.
From Criteria File
This is an advanced option for selecting hybridizations. See Using criteria files for a conceptual background of this process. To use this source, you will first need to upload an appropriate criteria file using the Upload a file link available from &mem_home;. If this has been done, the criteria filename should appear in the drop down box. Select the appropriate file, then click "Get Criteria File".
If the criteria file is well formed, a selection of Continuous Parameters and/or Categorical Parameters will be displayed. Use this selection interface to specify which hybridizations you want included. Hybridizations will be added to the analysis condition when you click "Add Hybrids to Condition".
Once you have added the hybridizations to the analysis condition, you are returned to the the Edit Analysis Condition page and can view the hybridizations that are currently part of the analysis condition. Hybridizations can be removed from the analysis condition by checking the "Delete" checkbox and hitting "Update".
When the configuration of the analysis condition is satisfactory, you can return to &mem_home; via the header links at the top of the page.

sect1.title: Create new set of conditions
sect1.para: This link allows users to create new analysis set. For an overview of this process, see Determining tree input.

To create a new analysis set, specify the condition name and description. As many analysis sets can represent the same data (if many analyses are performed), it is helpful to provide a description even though it is not mandatory. Also choose the PI/PI group that will own the analysis set. This will allow others in the group to use the analysis set. Click 'Next' to create the analysis set. Then you will be ready to specify which conditions to include in the analysis set.

sect1.title: Edit existing set of conditions
sect1.para:
This page allows users to modify analysis conditions included in the set of analysis conditions. To add conditions, choose the desired analysis set. From the "Edit Set of Conditions" page, click "Add Conditions". Click on the desired source, then click "Choose Condition Source" button. The use of each source is as follows:
Analysis Conditions
An existing analysis condition can be used as the source for analysis conditions. If this source is used, a list of analysis conditions you can read is displayed. You may select one or more analysis conditions by checking the checkbox beside the condition name. All selected analysis conditions will be included in the current analysis set once you click "Add Conditions".
Studies
An existing array study may be used as the source for analysis conditions. If this source is used, a list of array studies you can read is displayed. You may select one or more studies. Analysis conditions are automatically created that correspond to all experimental conditions that are part of the study. The new analysis conditions are included in the current analysis set once you click "Add Conditions".
Experimental Conditions
Existing experimental conditions may be used as the source for analysis sets. If this source is used, a list of experimental conditions that you have can read is displayed. You may select one or more experimental conditions. Analysis conditions are automatically created that correspond to all checked experimental conditions. The new analysis conditions are included in the current analysis set once you click "Add Conditions".
Experimental conditions are easily confused with analysis conditions as analysis conditions are derived from experimental conditions. Remember that experimental conditions are defined as part of an array study and are used by array orders. They relate to a specific experimental intent and are unchanging. Analysis conditions often mimic experimental conditions (as we wish to analyze data based on the intent of the experiment). However analysis condition is entirely theoretical and is subject to change. Users can change the grouping of hybridizations in analysis conditions at any time.

sect1.title: Update my personal info
sect1.para: Initial account information is set when the account is initially created. To update information change the appropriate values in the appropriate fields, and click "submit". Note that you can't change your user type. This information is provided for informational purposes only.
It is particularly important to keep your name, phone number, and email address up-to-date as this information is used by &product; and array center staff to communicate with you.

sect1.title: Change my password
sect1.para: To change your password, simply enter your old and new password in the appropriate fields. &password_rule;

sect1.title: Create a new group
sect1.para: This link allows users to create new groups to provide control over who can see and work with their data. To add a new group, simply click on this link and specify the name for the new group. This name should be meaningful to members of the group. Then click "Submit". After creating the group you can set the members using the Manage membership of my groups link.

sect1.title: Manage membership of my groups
sect1.para: This link allows users to control which users are part of their groups. Initially, each user owns one group (named after their login id). If necessary, users can create additional groups. To modify membership in a group, click this link and the click on the "Manage" button for the group you wish to edit. To add users to your group, check the checkboxes under "Is a member?" that correspond to the appropriate names and login ids. To remove users, simply uncheck the appropriate boxes. When the configuration is correct, save the changes by clicking "Finish".
